subject: RBNZ Assistant Governor Hawkesby says monetary policy cannot offset impact from coronavirus outbreak but can soften the blow

PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Crown Resorts stood down around 95% of staff either partially or fully but wil pay an interim dividend; South Korea ruling Democratic Party achieve landslide election victory
content:
AUSTRALIA

Aurizon Holdings (AZJ AT) - Co. Q3 above rail volumes 63.3mln tons vs. Prev. 62.0mln tons Y/Y. (Newswires)

Base Resources (BSE AT) - Co. affirms FY20 output on the basis of continued operations. (Newswires)

Bendigo and Adelaide Bank (BEN AT) - Co. withdraws H2 guidance due to uncertainty from coronavirus, while it announced support packages for businesses and personal clients. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. reports March CRM USD 4.62/bbl Y/Y vs. Prev. USD 8.67/bbl Y/Y, while CRM sales from production 515mln litres vs. Prev. 473mln litres. (Newswires)

Crown Resorts (CWN AT) - Co. has been forced to substantially reduce its work force in which it has stood down either fully or partially around 95% of its 11500 staff, while it is to pay an interim dividend and has agreed terms regarding a AUD 450mln project finance facility. (Newswires)

Decmil Group (DCG AT) - Co. is positive on the outlook of its Australia operations but has closed New Zealand unit Decmil Construction immediately. (Newswires)

IOOF Holdings (IFL AT) - Co. to divest New Zealand-based IOOF Integral Master Trust. (Newswires)

Transurban (TCL AT) - Co. Q3 average daily traffic fell 4.8% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAHA T) - Co. requests trading halt until either an announcement regarding restructuring or 7 days whichever is sooner. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) - Co.’s BT Super is in talks to shift its group life insurance from in-house to AIA Group (1299 HK). (The Australian)

Whitehaven Coal (WHC AT) - Co. Q3 ROM coal output 4.91mln tons vs. Prev. 4.90mln tons Y/Y, saleable coal output 4.1mln tons vs. Prev. 5.1mln tons Y/Y. (Newswires)

Woodside Petroleum (WPL AT) - Co. Q1 output rose 12% Y/Y to 24.2mln BOE vs. Prev. 25.7mln BOE the prior quarter, rev. USD 1.08bln vs. Prev. USD 1.22bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Toshiba (6502 JT) - Co. is to reduce business days this month at domestic facilities. (Newswires)

Toyota Industries (6201 JT) - Co. will suspend Nagakusa plant on April 20th-22nd. (Newswires)

Universal Entertainment Corp (6425 JT) - Co. cuts FY20 net guidance to JPY 26bln from JPY 32bln and rev. to JPY 175bln from JPY 190bln. (Newswires)

Unizo Holdings (3258 JT) - Co. announces it will not record JPY 6.6bln charge following cancellation of a land sale agreement. (Newswires)

Healthcare - Japan has vowed to purchase excess medical equipment if Co.s increase output. (Nikkei)

Relief Measures - Japanese PM Abe is said to warm to the proposal of JPY 100k handouts. (Nikkei)

Other News - Japan is considering including Aichi and Kyoto to its emergency declaration. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Elections - South Korea ruling party won a majority of parliament seats for the first time in 16 years with 180 seats and will not have to form a coalition. (Newswires)

Other News - BoK are reportedly to name 4 new policy members when their term ends this month. (Newswires)

subject: Texas oil regulators are to meet April 21st to further discuss production limits
analysis_details: • This follows Tuesday's meeting in which regulators heard over 10 hours of testimony but failed to table a proposal to reduce output. It is also worth noting that Texas has not reduced oil production since the 1970s although there has been mixed views from the industry on how to address the current demand shock.

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US COVID-19 cases rose 4.6% to 605,390 (Prev. +4.4% at 579,005), death toll rose 10.5% to 24,582 (Prev. +1.4% at 22,252). (Newswires)

US Small Business loan programme is expected to run out of money later today, exhausting the initial allocation of USD 350bln, according to WSJ citing a person familiar with the matter. (WSJ)

US House Majority Leader Hoyer said he can’t guarantee that an agreement will be reached than can also pass by Friday but is hopeful a deal will be reached with Friday as an optimal scenario. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi called President Trump's decision to pull WHO funding senseless, dangerous and illegal, while she added that it will swiftly be challenged. (Newswires)

New York Governor Cuomo said "it is over when we have a vaccine" which is expected in between 12 and 18 months, while he added that the reopen will be gradual with the priority on public health. (Newswires)

Milan is reportedly asking the government to restart activities on May 4th. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson spokesman said a review of social distancing measures will be considered by ministers and an announcement will be made on Thursday. (Newswires)

UK Health Minister said it is clear that it is too early to make changes to lockdown measures and suggested that high deaths will continue for at least a short while. (Newswires)

German government are to propose extending social distance measures until May 3rd which would be the base case scenario, according to a draft. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

  • Indian Trade Deficit Govt (USD)(Mar) -9.76B vs. Exp. -7.42B (Prev. -9.85B). (Newswires) 
  • Indian Exports (USD)(Mar) 21.41B (Prev. 27.65B)
  • Indian Imports (USD)(Mar) 31.16B (Prev. 37.5B) 

 

UK/EU

UK-EU trade talks will continue on week commencing: 20th April, 11th May and 1st June via a videocall. (BBC)

BoE said it is considering increasing holdings of Sterling supranational bonds over time and intend to purchase GBP 554mln of gilts over the next 3-months which will be separate to their QE programme. (Newswires)

ECB's Makhlouf is sceptical about a "V" shaped recovery and expects it to be more gradual, while he the ECB are ready to further support economies and citizens if events show more is needed to be done. (Newswires) 

 

FX

BoC left rates unchanged at 0.25% as expected and noted that the outlook is too uncertain to provide a forecast, while it announced the development of a new Provincial Bond Purchase Program of up to CAD 50bln and a Corporate Bond Purchase Program of CAD 10bln. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e 19.248M vs. Exp. 11.676M (Prev. 15.177M). (Newswires)

US tariffs on crude imports are still being considered, after the global oil deal according to US energy diplomat Fannon, while there were also reports that US is said to consider a plan to reduce production by paying drillers not to produce according to sources. (Newswires)

IEA Monthly Oil Market Report stated that global oil demand is set to fall by a record 9.3mln BPD in 2020 and SPR purchases can reach 200mln BPD in the next three months, while it added that no feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near-term demand losses although the past week's achievements are a solid start. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said global oil demand could decline by 8mln BPD in 2020 and that output cuts can be adjusted over the course of the year, while Russian President Putin commented it is important that members commit to output cut pledges. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Beige Book stated economic activity contracted sharply and abruptly across all regions in the US as a result of COVID-19 and that most districts reported declines in manufacturing but cited significant variation across industries. Furthermore, it noted that employment declined in all districts and steeply in many cases as the COVID-19 pandemic affected firms in many sectors, with many districts noting severe job cuts were widespread. (Newswires)

  • US Industrial Production (Mar) M/M -5.4% vs. Exp. -4.0% (Prev. 0.6%, Rev. 0.5%). (Newswires) 
  • US Retail Sales (Mar) M/M -8.7% vs. Exp. -8.0% (Prev. -0.5%, Rev. -0.4%) 
  • US NY Fed Manufacturing (Apr) -78.2 vs. Exp. -35.0 (Prev. -21.5) 

 

MARKET RECAP

Analysts have found it difficult to convincingly explain what was underpinning the Tuesday rally; and today, it is the opposite; a tone of risk-off has engulfed US stocks. It is easy to attribute the downside to dismal economic data, however, futures were trading red before the 0830 ET retail sales and Empire Fed (both grim, and worse than expected); the dollar was firmer on the session, and although pared back after the data, retained its bid. A stronger dollar has been associated with risk-off type trading recently. The Treasury curve meanwhile bull-flattened. Oil continues to slide; there were some dire warnings from the IEA on demand today as well as chunky inventory builds in the US. Early doors, bank earnings were in focus pre-market, particularly, the building of loan loss provisions. Goldman Sachs (GS) missed on EPS but beat on revenue, while Provision for credit losses were at USD 937mln (exp. 550mln, prev. 224mln). Its FICC revenue was up 33% Y/Y to 2.97bln which saw its bond trading results the strongest in five years. Although overall, results were hit by debt and equity holdings in its asset management business, but its trading topped expectations. Bank of America (BAC) also missed on EPS, revenue also fell slightly short. Loan loss provisions increased to USD 4.8bln, above estimates. BAC saw a similar story to JPM where EPS took a hit on the increased credit provisions but NII and NIM were strong at 12.13bln and 2.91%, both above expectations. In a call however, its CFO noted NII could approach 11bln in Q2 and expects the largest COVID impact on NII in Q2, and its CEO highlighted it has had an impact on every part of its business. Citi (C) beat on both EPS and revenue, while credit provisions rose to 7.03bln from 2.22bln last quarter. Elsewhere, United Health (UNH) are firmer after a decent report with top and bottom-line beats while it maintained its FY EPS view, noting it does not request or plan to request any government aid and airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV, JBLU, ALK) were firmer after the companies reached an agreement with the Treasury for payroll aid through the Payroll Support Program. SPX -2.2% at 2783, NDX -1.15% at 8592, DJIA -1.86% at 23,504.

The Treasury complex bull-flattened markedly on Wednesday as risk appetite soured. The bid gained traction overnight as European trade commenced. In essence, equity futures were reversing yesterday’s strength and a dump in crude futures (a gloomy IEA report and chunky inventory builds) kept the macro narrative defensive. Then as the heavy US data slate got underway, which was dire across all accounts with “worst-ever/since” headlines bombarding screens, Treasury strength continued, although how much of the move was reactionary to the data remains a point for debate as many are looking past near-term prints. One desk noted that real money had been booking profits and selling into the Fed’s Treasury purchases, which were accompanied by hefty offer-to-cover ratios, stalling the move lower in yields in the afternoon; at the same time, the desk noted that specs and CTAs were taking the other side of the trade. USD issuance was afoot on Wednesday, likely keeping a cap on Treasury strength, where participants digested a USD 7bln three-parter from Saudi Arabia (5s, 10s, 40s), as well as lumpy, post-earnings USD 10bln launched from JPMorgan (6s, 11s, 21s, 31s). By settlement, curve spreads had flattened, with 2s -2bps at 0.20%, 10s -11bps at 0.64%, and 30s -14bps at 1.27%. Meanwhile, in STIRs, nearby Eurodollar futures rallied, with desks noting block trades in the May contract, coming amid the launch of the Fed’s CPFF, which will be supportive of the depression of USD LIBOR from its elevated levels; the move signals the market’s confidence that LIBOR will fall further in the next month or so. US T-note futures (M0) settled 30 ticks higher at 139-05.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 15th: Risk sentiment sours ahead of key jobless claims data
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Trump to pull WHO funding and says some states may reopen this month; BAC, C, GS take profit hits as credit provisions baloon; US crude stocks build 19mln bbls, IEA sees April oil demand -29mln BPD.
  • COMING UP: Data: US Initial Jobless Claims, Building Permits. AU employment. EU Industrial Production, GE CPI. Events: OPEC Monthly Oil Report, G20 FinMin meeting. Supply: JP, UK, FR & SP. Earnings: MS, BLK, ABT, LVMH

MARKET WRAP

Analysts have found it difficult to convincingly explain what was underpinning the Tuesday rally; and today, it is the opposite; a tone of risk-off has engulfed US stocks. It is easy to attribute the downside to dismal economic data, however, futures were trading red before the 0830 ET retail sales and Empire Fed (both grim, and worse than expected); the dollar was firmer on the session, and although pared back after the data, retained its bid. A stronger dollar has been associated with risk-off type trading recently. The Treasury curve meanwhile bull-flattened. Oil continues to slide; there were some dire warnings from the IEA on demand today as well as chunky inventory builds in the US. Early doors, bank earnings were in focus pre-market, particularly, the building of loan loss provisions. Looking ahead, the focus will be on Thursday’s initial jobless claims data, which analysts expect to print 5.105mln.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

Figures provided as of Wednesday (via state offcial health departments) against Tuesday:

  • US cases rise +4.6% to 605,390 (prev. +4.4% at 579,005), death toll rises 10.5% to 24,582 (prev. +1.4% at 22,252).
  • New York COVID-19 cases +5.7% to 213,779 (prev. +3.7% at 202,208); death toll rises +6.9% to 11,586 (prev. +7.7% at 10,834)
  • ITALY cases rise by 1.6% to 165,155 (prev. +1.9% at 162,488), death toll rises by 2.7% to 21,645 (prev. +2.9% at 21,067).
  • SPAIN cases rose to 177,633 (prev. 172,541), death toll rises to 18,579 (prev. 18,056).
  • GERMANY cases rose by 2486 to 127584, death toll rose by 285 to 3254.
  • FRANCE cases rise 5.48% to 106,206 (prev. +5.6% to 103,573); death toll +12.1% at 17,167 (Prev. +5.1% to 15,729).
  • UK COVID-19 cases rise to 98,476 (prev. 93,873), death toll rises to 12,868 (prev. 12,107); deaths rise by 761 (+6.29%) vs. yesterday's increase of 778 (+6.87%).
  • SWITZERLAND cases rise to 26,336 (prev. 25,834), death toll rises to 973 (prev. 900).
  • CANADA cases rise to 27,540 (prev. 27,063), death toll rises to 954 (prev. 903).

GLOBAL

WHO: President Trump stated that he instructed the administration to halt funding to the WHO as a review is being conducted. House Democrats said Trump has no authority to block WHO funds and there were also comments from UN Secretary General Guterres that now is not the time to reduce resources for operations amid the pandemic.

NORTH AMERICA

GEOPOLITICS: China could be secretly conducting nuclear tests with very low explosive power, raising concern that it might be in breach of international law, according to a new arms-control report to be soon made public by the State Department, cited by WSJ. Furthermore, US Defense Secretary Esper said China could have have been more transparent earlier, saying that even today China is holding information on COVID-19.

STIMULUS: The Small Business loan programme is expected to run out of money later on Wednesday, exhausting the initial allocation of USD 350bln, according to WSJ citing a person familiar with the matter. Both Democrats and Republicans have been debating over fresh funds for the programme but have not yet been able to come to an agreement. Earlier, there were comments from US House Majority Leader Hoyer, who said he can’t guarantee that an agreement will be reached than can also pass by Friday, but is hopeful an agreement will be reached with Friday as an optimal scenario.

LOCKDOWN: President Trump said plans to reopen the country are nearing completion and he will speak to all Governors shortly as well as authorise them to open states in the appropriate time and manner, which could happen for some before May 1st.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOC: The bank of Canada left rates unchanged at its lower bound of 0.25% as expected. The bank decided not to release its economic projections given the current situation it would not be able to provide an accurate forecast. Although it stated that bank analysis of alternative scenarios suggests the level of real activity was down 1-3% in Q1 and will be 15-30% lower in Q2 than in Q4 2019. CPI is expected to be close to 0% in Q2 2020, primarily due to the transitory effects of lower gasoline prices. The bank announced two new programmes: the Provincial Bond Purchase Program of up to CAD 50bln (2% of GDP) and the Corporate Bond Purchase Programme of CAD 10bln (0.4% of GDP); both are to be put in place in the coming weeks. Capital Economics highlighted that the size of these programmes are relatively small, and could signal any future policy moves may involve expanding these programmes. The BoC also enhanced its term repo facility to permit funding for up to 24-months, and temporarily increased the amount of Treasury Bills it acquires at auctions to up to 40% (from 20%); CapEco suggests this is aimed at improving the market function rather than increasing the budget deficit. In the press conference, outgoing Governor Poloz reiterated actions taken currently are to improve the functioning of markets, and reiterated that the BOC would stand ready to adjust the scale or duration of programs if necessary. The press conference saw little new information, although Deputy Governor Wilkins noted that credit easing is part of its tools, she did not want to speculate on any future possible use of the aforementioned tools. Governor Poloz noted rates would be very low throughout the recovery phase, and when asked about whether he would stay on as Governor (this was his last rate decision) he stated the bank is sticking with its plan to choose a successor, which is 90% done.

PBOC cut the one-year rate on its Medium-term Lending Facility (MLF) by 20bps to 2.95%, an all-time low. Capital Economics says the move makes it likely that the Loan Prime Rate (LPR) will decline on Monday, providing lower borrowing costs; the LPR is set by bank quotations which are then determined by a spread over the MLF. The consultancy believes another 100bps of rate reductions across policy instruments will take place this year.

ECB: ECB’s Makhlouf is sceptical about a “V” shaped recovery and expects it to be more gradual. Makhlouf added the ECB is ready to support economies and citizens even further if it requires. Elsewhere, the ECB announced it supported the action taken by macroprudential authorities to address the financial sector by releasing or reducing capital buffers.

EUROPE

STIMULUS: Eurogroup head Centeno did not rule out using ‘coronabonds’ as part of a response to the COVID-19; he expects the EC to give guidance on the proposed recovery fund on April 23rd, adding that part of the fund needs to be available for Spring/Summer. Meanwhile, France is to issue EUR 245bln of medium and long-term bonds net of buybacks this year, up from the March estimate of EUR 210bln; to raise outstanding stocks of T-Bills by an additional EUR 34.6bln, according to the AFT. France had been in favour of coronabonds, although it is now raising its issuance after the Eurogroup failed to agree on such (as was expected).

LOCKDOWN: European Commission President von der Leyen said EU countries should use a “gradual tailor-made approach” to lifting lockdown restrictions, adding that recommendations focus on three main preconditions: 1) a significant decrease in the spread of the coronavirus; 2) sufficient health system capacity; 3) adequate surveillance and monitoring capacity. Meanwhile, according to Handelsblatt, the German government is set to extend COVID-19 restrictions until May 3rd. German Chancellor Merkel says any further relaxation of lockdown will be dependent on how the infection rate develops, little room to manoeuvre

BREXIT: Brexit negotiators have conducted a video call on Wednesday to finalise next week’s large-scale trade negotiations, as well as discuss a potential extension to the transition period amid COVID-19, the Telegraph reported. However, FT said recently that the UK is holding out on providing EU with detailed fishing rights proposals which could derail approaching talks. The Express noted that the UK is pressing on with sealing a Brexit deal by the end of the year despite reservations from Brussels; EU member states have agreed that areas, where both sides agree, should not be allowed to progress too far ahead while talks stall on the more contentious areas – such as fisheries and level playing field. Surprisingly, EU27 diplomats have been told there are several areas of convergence where deals can be struck with relative ease, but ‘very, very big gaps’ still need to be bridged where both sides disagree.

UK: The government, on Thursday, is likely to announce that lockdown will remain until at least May 7th. UK Health Minister later said it is clear that it is too early to make changes to lockdown measures; high deaths will continue for at least a short while. Note a COBRA meeting will take place on Thursday to determine the official government guidance.

DATA

US RETAIL SALES: Although monthly March retail sales data showed a decline deeper than analysts were expecting, some analysts took comfort in some of the internals; the control Group (which feeds into GDP) fell by 1.7%, not as bad as the -2.0% the Street was expecting. BMO said that data collection was always going to be a concern, and notes the report stated “many businesses are operating in a limited capacity or have ceased operations completely. As a result, their ability to provide accurate, timely information to Census may be limited.” Additionally, the report said “data collection is now occurring primarily via email requests and online reporting”; BMO argues that this suggests that firms that are shut down are not reporting, therefore potentially skewing the core numbers higher.

EMPIRE STATE MANUFACTURING: Last month’s record dropped was usurped by the April data, which saw a record fall of 56.7 points to -78.20, way below the Street’s -35.0 expectation. To highlight the magnitude, analysts note that the low in 2008 was -34.3, making it clear that manufacturing is being hit as hard as the services sector. The sub-indices all declined, with the exception of delivery times, which rose because supply chains have shut down, Pantheon said. “The average level of the key Empire State components points to the national ISM manufacturing index falling to about 35; the December 2008 low was 34.5,” Pantheon writes, “whether that level is undershot in April or May doesn’t matter; the point is that manufacturing is in meltdown.”

INDUSTRIAL/MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION: Industrial production drops by the most since 1946, consistent with manufacturing contracting by 20% annualised, Capital Economics says. US industrial production dropped by a hefty 5.4% M/M in March - deeper than the 4.0% decline analysts had expected, and the largest monthly fall since 1946, once again highlighting that the manufacturing side of the economy is being hammered as much as the services side. Manufacturing production itself fell by 6.3% M/M, also the largest monthly drop since WW2, mainly due to the fall in motor vehicle production, but every industry group saw output fall - even food and beverages, despite the panic buying seen in the month. “With many factories only being shut down in the last couple of weeks of last month, however, the March data will capture only part of the associated hit to activity,” Capital Economics says, “indeed, the collapse in the Empire State manufacturing index to a record low of -78.2 in April, from -21.5, leaves it consistent with manufacturing output falling at a 20% annualised pace.”

BUSINESS INVENTORIES: Business inventories fell 0.4% in March, as expected, a slightly larger decline than the prior revised -0.3%. Oxford Economics highlights that businesses were not stocking inventories ahead of the coronavirus outbreak, noting impact on both demand and supply strains will leave inventories under pressure. It adds that “economic activity should start to rebound in the latter half of 2020, but risks are heavily tilted to the downside.”

CRUDE

WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 0.24 LOWER AT USD 19.87/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 1.91 LOWER AT USD 27.69/BBL

Crude futures continued their post-OPEC + decline on Wednesday as ballooning inventories, dismal IEA forecasts, and US data, and little risk appetite all sunk their teeth. Prices continued lower in APAC and European trade, after the bearish private US inventories report on Tuesday, and particularly after the IEA posted its gloomy monthly report today (see below). At the same time, making the losses more acute was the paring of risk appetite in equities. The selling pressure found no reprieve in the US session either as the EIA weekly report showed crude stocks (bbls) building a record 19.2mln, gasoline +5mln, distillates +6mln; production fell by 100k BPD to 12.3mln BPD, although with storage reaching capacity, the cut will make little difference to the global supply glut. Elsewhere, Saudi Aramco has offered Asian and European refineries a payment deferral for crude cargoes by up to 90 days, sources reported; at least three refiners rejected the terms due to higher financing costs. However, Saudi later claimed such reports were false. Note, in the tail end of the session (post-settlement) reports were suggesting the US is considering a plan which would pay oil producers not to produce.

IEA MONTHLY OIL MARKET REPORT sees Global oil demand set to fall by a record 9.3mln BPD in 2020, potentially down by 29mln BPD in April. The report said SPR purchases could reach 200mln BPD in the next three months - still awaiting details on stock purchases. No feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near-term demand losses - “however, the past week’s achievements are a solid start.” Predicts output falls by other countries, such as the US and Canada, could be around 3.5mln amid lower prices.

OPEC: Mexico will curtail production by 100k BPD in the months of May-June only, according to the Mexican Energy Minister; this is in-fitting with the OPEC+ pact announced over the weekend. OPEC initially wanted the country to cut output by 400k BPD, talks at the time hit a snag amid a rift between Saudi and Mexico. US stepped in as stated it will take some of the curtailment burden off Mexico (US committed to shoulder 250k BPD cuts on Mexico’s behalf). Meanwhile, in Russia, oil companies in the country are examining which wells they will curtail production at, looking mainly at mature fields where production was falling anyway, amid Moscow’s commitment for its largest-ever output cut, sources reported. Sources close to industry and government said that Moscow was preparing to cut its production by around 2mln BPD anyway amid the poor demand outlook.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 30 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-05.

The Treasury complex bull-flattened markedly on Wednesday as risk appetite soured. The bid gained traction overnight as European trade commenced. In essence, equity futures were reversing yesterday’s strength and a dump in crude futures (a gloomy IEA report and chunky inventory builds) kept the macro narrative defensive. Then as the heavy US data slate got underway, which was dire across all accounts with “worst-ever/since” headlines bombarding screens, Treasury strength continued, although how much of the move was reactionary to the data remains a point for debate as many are looking past near-term prints. One desk noted that real money had been booking profits and selling into the Fed’s Treasury purchases, which were accompanied by hefty offer-to-cover ratios, stalling the move lower in yields in the afternoon; at the same time, the desk noted that specs and CTAs were taking the other side of the trade. USD issuance was afoot on Wednesday, likely keeping a cap on Treasury strength, where participants digested a USD 7bln three-parter from Saudi Arabia (5s, 10s, 40s), as well as lumpy, post-earnings USD 10bln launched from JPMorgan (6s, 11s, 21s, 31s). By settlement, curve spreads had flattened, with 2s -2bps at 0.20%, 10s -11bps at 0.64%, and 30s -14bps at 1.27%. Meanwhile, in STIRs, nearby Eurodollar futures rallied, with desks noting block trades in the May contract, coming amid the launch of the Fed’s CPFF, which will be supportive of the depression of USD LIBOR from its elevated levels; the move signals the market’s confidence that LIBOR will fall further in the next month or so.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -2.2% at 2783, NDX -1.15% at 8592, DJIA -1.86% at 23,504.

SECTORS: Energy -4.7%, Materials -4.5%, Financials -4.37%, Real Estate -3.8%, Utilities -3.36%, Industrials -2.8%, Communication svs -2.8%, Technology -2.2%, Consumer Discretionary -1.57%, Consumer Staples -1.56%, Health Care -0.5%

EARNINGS: Goldman Sachs (GS) missed on EPS but beat on revenue, while Provision for credit losses were at USD 937mln (exp. 550mln, prev. 224mln). Its FICC revenue was up 33% Y/Y to 2.97bln which saw its bond trading results the strongest in five years. Although overall, results were hit by debt and equity holdings in its asset management business, but its trading topped expectations. Bank of America (BAC) also missed on EPS, revenue also fell slightly short. Loan loss provisions increased to USD 4.8bln, above estimates. BAC saw a similar story to JPM where EPS took a hit on the increased credit provisions but NII and NIM were strong at 12.13bln and 2.91%, both above expectations. In a call however, its CFO noted NII could approach 11bln in Q2 and expects the largest COVID impact on NII in Q2, and its CEO highlighted it has had an impact on every part of its business. Citi (C) beat on both EPS and revenue, while credit provisions rose to 7.03bln from 2.22bln last quarter. Fixed Income Markets revenue rose 39% to USD 4.8bln, reflecting strength in rates, currencies and commodities. Equity Markets revenue that rose 39% to USD 1.2bln with strong performance in derivatives; includes higher client activity as a result of the higher volatility. Regional bank PNC Financial (PNC) beat on EPS and revenue, NII fell Q/Q, while credit loss provisions rose 693mln to 914mln. US Bancorp (USB) missed on EPS but beat on revenue while NII declined, Provision for credit losses stood at 993mln (+600mln); note some desks highlight the regionals may have to increase its provisions in the upcoming quarters. Elsewhere, United Health (UNH) are firmer after a decent report with top and bottom-line beats while it maintained its FY EPS view, noting it does not request or plan to request any government aid.

STOCK NEWS: Airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV, JBLU, ALK) firmer after the companies reached an agreement with the Treasury for payroll aid through the Payroll Support Program. Procter & Gamble (PG) increased its quarterly dividend by 6% to USD 0.79 and it also announced it is advancing its Q3 earnings release to April 17th from April 21st. Tesla (TSLA) China registrations rose 450% m/m to 12,079 units, according to LMC Automotive. Visa Inc. (V) & Mastercard were downgraded to Hold from Buy at Jefferies.

Q1 BANK CREDIT PROVISIONS: JPM provisions USD 8.3bln (+6.8bln); C provisions USD 7bln (+4.8bln); BAC provisions USD 4.8bln (+3.6bln); WFC provisions USD 4bln (+3bln); USB provisions USD 993mln (+600mln); GS provisions USD 937mln (+601mln); PNC provisions USD 914mln (+702mln).

FOREX

DOLLARS HAVEN STATUS CONTINUES TO HOLD AS SENTIMENT FLIPS

USD: DXY rose amid sour risk sentiment, seeing the greenback benefit from its haven properties. DXY the 99 figure and saw highs around 99.80, although since a dismal slate of US data, it has pared and sits around the 99.50 handle at pixel time; yields were lower across the curve (bull-flattening) which likely limited some of the upside.

JPY: “USDJPY hasn’t been trading well with risk sentiment recently,” Citi writes, while equities are lower today but USDJPY firmer as dollar strength dominates the Yen which saw USDJPY trade within 106.94-107.84. Citi highlight the 106.90 level as area as support which held true today, and the desk writes “if this level continues to hold, we could see the pair retest 108.30 where the 200dma converges with the horizontal resistance. However, a close below there would open the way for downside acceleration towards 104.50”.

EUR: Weighed by narrowing Bund/BTP spreads after Italy announced it would hold larger bond auctions and plans for more costly syndicated debt placements for shorter maturities to finance ramped-up spending to respond to the virus fallout. Additionally, desks continue to cite disappointment with the Eurogroup’s response package announced last week (specifically, the absence of Eurozone joint debt issuance). EURUSD however picked up off lows slightly and is now back above 109 just shy of the 50hma at 1.0942.

XAU: Has given back some of Tuesday’s gains, which saw it rise to a fresh 7-year high. Credit Suisse says “the resilience of gold points to markets view that as central bank balance sheets across the world both expand in size and deteriorate in quality, gold should benefit as the ultimate of expression of resistance to likely global monetisation of increasingly weak fiscal outlooks.”

CAD: The Loonie was hit in the morning as crude prices tumbled, and declines accelerated after an update form the IEA, which sees global oil demand falling by a record 9.3mln BPD, while adding that no feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near term demand losses. The BoC resulted in little by way of price action, despite announcing two new programmes (PBPP and CBPP), although the size of these are relatively small.

AUD: After seven consecutive days of gains, the recovery has been halted by a weak consumer sentiment report and a soft risk environment. The Aussie fell beneath its 50dma around 0.6364. Participants will be eyeing jobs data later on tonight; RBC suggests that we are likely to see some impact despite the survey period being prior before the increased social distancing measures as businesses “began to stand down or shed labour amid a reduction in turnover and expectations of tougher restrictions.”

GBP: Sterling recent rally came to a pause as risk sentiment soured seeing Cable move from highs of 1.2630 to lows of 1.2439. GBPUSD failed to breach it’s 200 dma at 1.2657 (a level to keep an eye on) while some highlight strong demand beneath 1.25. The number of new deaths continues to slow slightly in the UK although officials are waiting for further clarification before suggesting a peak has been reached. The Health Minister announced it is too early to make changes to lockdown measures, while high deaths will continue for a while. On Brexit, the UK is sticking to its roots and is not expected to request an extension by the end of June deadline, with negotiations set to take place on April 20th, May 11th, and June 1st via a video call.

EMFX: EMFX in general was weaker against the buck today amid soured risk appetite. ZAR, MXN & RUB underperformed amid a poor day for oil prices while some weakness in BRL was explained by the resignation of its Health Secretary amid indifferences with President Bolsonaro.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 15th: Risk sentiment sours ahead of key jobless claims data
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Trump to pull WHO funding and says some states may reopen this month; BAC, C, GS take profit hits as credit provisions baloon; US crude stocks build 19mln bbls, IEA sees April oil demand -29mln BPD.
  • COMING UP: Data: US Initial Jobless Claims, Building Permits. AU employment. EU Industrial Production, GE CPI. Events: OPEC Monthly Oil Report, G20 FinMin meeting. Supply: JP, UK, FR & SP. Earnings: MS, BLK, ABT, LVMH

MARKET WRAP

Analysts have found it difficult to convincingly explain what was underpinning the Tuesday rally; and today, it is the opposite; a tone of risk-off has engulfed US stocks. It is easy to attribute the downside to dismal economic data, however, futures were trading red before the 0830 ET retail sales and Empire Fed (both grim, and worse than expected); the dollar was firmer on the session, and although pared back after the data, retained its bid. A stronger dollar has been associated with risk-off type trading recently. The Treasury curve meanwhile bull-flattened. Oil continues to slide; there were some dire warnings from the IEA on demand today as well as chunky inventory builds in the US. Early doors, bank earnings were in focus pre-market, particularly, the building of loan loss provisions. Looking ahead, the focus will be on Thursday’s initial jobless claims data, which analysts expect to print 5.105mln.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

Figures provided as of Wednesday (via state offcial health departments) against Tuesday:

  • US cases rise +4.6% to 605,390 (prev. +4.4% at 579,005), death toll rises 10.5% to 24,582 (prev. +1.4% at 22,252).
  • New York COVID-19 cases +5.7% to 213,779 (prev. +3.7% at 202,208); death toll rises +6.9% to 11,586 (prev. +7.7% at 10,834)
  • ITALY cases rise by 1.6% to 165,155 (prev. +1.9% at 162,488), death toll rises by 2.7% to 21,645 (prev. +2.9% at 21,067).
  • SPAIN cases rose to 177,633 (prev. 172,541), death toll rises to 18,579 (prev. 18,056).
  • GERMANY cases rose by 2486 to 127584, death toll rose by 285 to 3254.
  • FRANCE cases rise 5.48% to 106,206 (prev. +5.6% to 103,573); death toll +12.1% at 17,167 (Prev. +5.1% to 15,729).
  • UK COVID-19 cases rise to 98,476 (prev. 93,873), death toll rises to 12,868 (prev. 12,107); deaths rise by 761 (+6.29%) vs. yesterday's increase of 778 (+6.87%).
  • SWITZERLAND cases rise to 26,336 (prev. 25,834), death toll rises to 973 (prev. 900).
  • CANADA cases rise to 27,540 (prev. 27,063), death toll rises to 954 (prev. 903).

GLOBAL

WHO: President Trump stated that he instructed the administration to halt funding to the WHO as a review is being conducted. House Democrats said Trump has no authority to block WHO funds and there were also comments from UN Secretary General Guterres that now is not the time to reduce resources for operations amid the pandemic.

NORTH AMERICA

GEOPOLITICS: China could be secretly conducting nuclear tests with very low explosive power, raising concern that it might be in breach of international law, according to a new arms-control report to be soon made public by the State Department, cited by WSJ. Furthermore, US Defense Secretary Esper said China could have have been more transparent earlier, saying that even today China is holding information on COVID-19.

STIMULUS: The Small Business loan programme is expected to run out of money later on Wednesday, exhausting the initial allocation of USD 350bln, according to WSJ citing a person familiar with the matter. Both Democrats and Republicans have been debating over fresh funds for the programme but have not yet been able to come to an agreement. Earlier, there were comments from US House Majority Leader Hoyer, who said he can’t guarantee that an agreement will be reached than can also pass by Friday, but is hopeful an agreement will be reached with Friday as an optimal scenario.

LOCKDOWN: President Trump said plans to reopen the country are nearing completion and he will speak to all Governors shortly as well as authorise them to open states in the appropriate time and manner, which could happen for some before May 1st.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOC: The bank of Canada left rates unchanged at its lower bound of 0.25% as expected. The bank decided not to release its economic projections given the current situation it would not be able to provide an accurate forecast. Although it stated that bank analysis of alternative scenarios suggests the level of real activity was down 1-3% in Q1 and will be 15-30% lower in Q2 than in Q4 2019. CPI is expected to be close to 0% in Q2 2020, primarily due to the transitory effects of lower gasoline prices. The bank announced two new programmes: the Provincial Bond Purchase Program of up to CAD 50bln (2% of GDP) and the Corporate Bond Purchase Programme of CAD 10bln (0.4% of GDP); both are to be put in place in the coming weeks. Capital Economics highlighted that the size of these programmes are relatively small, and could signal any future policy moves may involve expanding these programmes. The BoC also enhanced its term repo facility to permit funding for up to 24-months, and temporarily increased the amount of Treasury Bills it acquires at auctions to up to 40% (from 20%); CapEco suggests this is aimed at improving the market function rather than increasing the budget deficit. In the press conference, outgoing Governor Poloz reiterated actions taken currently are to improve the functioning of markets, and reiterated that the BOC would stand ready to adjust the scale or duration of programs if necessary. The press conference saw little new information, although Deputy Governor Wilkins noted that credit easing is part of its tools, she did not want to speculate on any future possible use of the aforementioned tools. Governor Poloz noted rates would be very low throughout the recovery phase, and when asked about whether he would stay on as Governor (this was his last rate decision) he stated the bank is sticking with its plan to choose a successor, which is 90% done.

PBOC cut the one-year rate on its Medium-term Lending Facility (MLF) by 20bps to 2.95%, an all-time low. Capital Economics says the move makes it likely that the Loan Prime Rate (LPR) will decline on Monday, providing lower borrowing costs; the LPR is set by bank quotations which are then determined by a spread over the MLF. The consultancy believes another 100bps of rate reductions across policy instruments will take place this year.

ECB: ECB’s Makhlouf is sceptical about a “V” shaped recovery and expects it to be more gradual. Makhlouf added the ECB is ready to support economies and citizens even further if it requires. Elsewhere, the ECB announced it supported the action taken by macroprudential authorities to address the financial sector by releasing or reducing capital buffers.

EUROPE

STIMULUS: Eurogroup head Centeno did not rule out using ‘coronabonds’ as part of a response to the COVID-19; he expects the EC to give guidance on the proposed recovery fund on April 23rd, adding that part of the fund needs to be available for Spring/Summer. Meanwhile, France is to issue EUR 245bln of medium and long-term bonds net of buybacks this year, up from the March estimate of EUR 210bln; to raise outstanding stocks of T-Bills by an additional EUR 34.6bln, according to the AFT. France had been in favour of coronabonds, although it is now raising its issuance after the Eurogroup failed to agree on such (as was expected).

LOCKDOWN: European Commission President von der Leyen said EU countries should use a “gradual tailor-made approach” to lifting lockdown restrictions, adding that recommendations focus on three main preconditions: 1) a significant decrease in the spread of the coronavirus; 2) sufficient health system capacity; 3) adequate surveillance and monitoring capacity. Meanwhile, according to Handelsblatt, the German government is set to extend COVID-19 restrictions until May 3rd. German Chancellor Merkel says any further relaxation of lockdown will be dependent on how the infection rate develops, little room to manoeuvre

BREXIT: Brexit negotiators have conducted a video call on Wednesday to finalise next week’s large-scale trade negotiations, as well as discuss a potential extension to the transition period amid COVID-19, the Telegraph reported. However, FT said recently that the UK is holding out on providing EU with detailed fishing rights proposals which could derail approaching talks. The Express noted that the UK is pressing on with sealing a Brexit deal by the end of the year despite reservations from Brussels; EU member states have agreed that areas, where both sides agree, should not be allowed to progress too far ahead while talks stall on the more contentious areas – such as fisheries and level playing field. Surprisingly, EU27 diplomats have been told there are several areas of convergence where deals can be struck with relative ease, but ‘very, very big gaps’ still need to be bridged where both sides disagree.

UK: The government, on Thursday, is likely to announce that lockdown will remain until at least May 7th. UK Health Minister later said it is clear that it is too early to make changes to lockdown measures; high deaths will continue for at least a short while. Note a COBRA meeting will take place on Thursday to determine the official government guidance.

DATA

US RETAIL SALES: Although monthly March retail sales data showed a decline deeper than analysts were expecting, some analysts took comfort in some of the internals; the control Group (which feeds into GDP) fell by 1.7%, not as bad as the -2.0% the Street was expecting. BMO said that data collection was always going to be a concern, and notes the report stated “many businesses are operating in a limited capacity or have ceased operations completely. As a result, their ability to provide accurate, timely information to Census may be limited.” Additionally, the report said “data collection is now occurring primarily via email requests and online reporting”; BMO argues that this suggests that firms that are shut down are not reporting, therefore potentially skewing the core numbers higher.

EMPIRE STATE MANUFACTURING: Last month’s record dropped was usurped by the April data, which saw a record fall of 56.7 points to -78.20, way below the Street’s -35.0 expectation. To highlight the magnitude, analysts note that the low in 2008 was -34.3, making it clear that manufacturing is being hit as hard as the services sector. The sub-indices all declined, with the exception of delivery times, which rose because supply chains have shut down, Pantheon said. “The average level of the key Empire State components points to the national ISM manufacturing index falling to about 35; the December 2008 low was 34.5,” Pantheon writes, “whether that level is undershot in April or May doesn’t matter; the point is that manufacturing is in meltdown.”

INDUSTRIAL/MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION: Industrial production drops by the most since 1946, consistent with manufacturing contracting by 20% annualised, Capital Economics says. US industrial production dropped by a hefty 5.4% M/M in March - deeper than the 4.0% decline analysts had expected, and the largest monthly fall since 1946, once again highlighting that the manufacturing side of the economy is being hammered as much as the services side. Manufacturing production itself fell by 6.3% M/M, also the largest monthly drop since WW2, mainly due to the fall in motor vehicle production, but every industry group saw output fall - even food and beverages, despite the panic buying seen in the month. “With many factories only being shut down in the last couple of weeks of last month, however, the March data will capture only part of the associated hit to activity,” Capital Economics says, “indeed, the collapse in the Empire State manufacturing index to a record low of -78.2 in April, from -21.5, leaves it consistent with manufacturing output falling at a 20% annualised pace.”

BUSINESS INVENTORIES: Business inventories fell 0.4% in March, as expected, a slightly larger decline than the prior revised -0.3%. Oxford Economics highlights that businesses were not stocking inventories ahead of the coronavirus outbreak, noting impact on both demand and supply strains will leave inventories under pressure. It adds that “economic activity should start to rebound in the latter half of 2020, but risks are heavily tilted to the downside.”

CRUDE

WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 0.24 LOWER AT USD 19.87/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 1.91 LOWER AT USD 27.69/BBL

Crude futures continued their post-OPEC + decline on Wednesday as ballooning inventories, dismal IEA forecasts, and US data, and little risk appetite all sunk their teeth. Prices continued lower in APAC and European trade, after the bearish private US inventories report on Tuesday, and particularly after the IEA posted its gloomy monthly report today (see below). At the same time, making the losses more acute was the paring of risk appetite in equities. The selling pressure found no reprieve in the US session either as the EIA weekly report showed crude stocks (bbls) building a record 19.2mln, gasoline +5mln, distillates +6mln; production fell by 100k BPD to 12.3mln BPD, although with storage reaching capacity, the cut will make little difference to the global supply glut. Elsewhere, Saudi Aramco has offered Asian and European refineries a payment deferral for crude cargoes by up to 90 days, sources reported; at least three refiners rejected the terms due to higher financing costs. However, Saudi later claimed such reports were false. Note, in the tail end of the session (post-settlement) reports were suggesting the US is considering a plan which would pay oil producers not to produce.

IEA MONTHLY OIL MARKET REPORT sees Global oil demand set to fall by a record 9.3mln BPD in 2020, potentially down by 29mln BPD in April. The report said SPR purchases could reach 200mln BPD in the next three months - still awaiting details on stock purchases. No feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near-term demand losses - “however, the past week’s achievements are a solid start.” Predicts output falls by other countries, such as the US and Canada, could be around 3.5mln amid lower prices.

OPEC: Mexico will curtail production by 100k BPD in the months of May-June only, according to the Mexican Energy Minister; this is in-fitting with the OPEC+ pact announced over the weekend. OPEC initially wanted the country to cut output by 400k BPD, talks at the time hit a snag amid a rift between Saudi and Mexico. US stepped in as stated it will take some of the curtailment burden off Mexico (US committed to shoulder 250k BPD cuts on Mexico’s behalf). Meanwhile, in Russia, oil companies in the country are examining which wells they will curtail production at, looking mainly at mature fields where production was falling anyway, amid Moscow’s commitment for its largest-ever output cut, sources reported. Sources close to industry and government said that Moscow was preparing to cut its production by around 2mln BPD anyway amid the poor demand outlook.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLED 30 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-05.

The Treasury complex bull-flattened markedly on Wednesday as risk appetite soured. The bid gained traction overnight as European trade commenced. In essence, equity futures were reversing yesterday’s strength and a dump in crude futures (a gloomy IEA report and chunky inventory builds) kept the macro narrative defensive. Then as the heavy US data slate got underway, which was dire across all accounts with “worst-ever/since” headlines bombarding screens, Treasury strength continued, although how much of the move was reactionary to the data remains a point for debate as many are looking past near-term prints. One desk noted that real money had been booking profits and selling into the Fed’s Treasury purchases, which were accompanied by hefty offer-to-cover ratios, stalling the move lower in yields in the afternoon; at the same time, the desk noted that specs and CTAs were taking the other side of the trade. USD issuance was afoot on Wednesday, likely keeping a cap on Treasury strength, where participants digested a USD 7bln three-parter from Saudi Arabia (5s, 10s, 40s), as well as lumpy, post-earnings USD 10bln launched from JPMorgan (6s, 11s, 21s, 31s). By settlement, curve spreads had flattened, with 2s -2bps at 0.20%, 10s -11bps at 0.64%, and 30s -14bps at 1.27%. Meanwhile, in STIRs, nearby Eurodollar futures rallied, with desks noting block trades in the May contract, coming amid the launch of the Fed’s CPFF, which will be supportive of the depression of USD LIBOR from its elevated levels; the move signals the market’s confidence that LIBOR will fall further in the next month or so.

EQUITIES

subject: China holdings of US Treasuries rise to USD 1.092trln in Feb (vs 1.079trln in Jan); Japan holdings of US Treasuries rose to USD 1.268trln in Feb (vs 1.212 in Jan)
Treasury in UK is reportedly set to unveil a sweeping rescue package for start up businesses within the next few days, according to The Telegraph
US reportedly considering a plan to reduce production by paying drillers not to produce, according to sources
California Governor Newsom says 2.7mln jobless claims have been filed within the last four weeks
FX WRAP: Dollars haven status continues to hold as sentiment flips
content:

Credit Suisse says "the resilience of gold points to markets view that as central bank balance sheets across the world both expand in size and deteriorate in quality, gold should benefit as the ultimate of expression of resistance to likely global monetization of increasingly weak fiscal outlooks."

CAD: The Loonie was hit in the morning as crude prices tumbled, and declines accelerated after an update form the IEA, which sees global oil demand falling by a record 9.3mln BPD, while adding that no feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near term demand losses. The BoC resulted in little by way of price action, despite announcing two new programmes (PBPP and CBPP), although the size of these are relatively small.

AUD: After seven consecutive days of gains, the recovery has been halted by a weak consumer sentiment report and a soft risk environment. The Aussie fell beneath its 50dma around 0.6364. Participants will be eyeing jobs data later on tonight; RBC suggests that we are likely to see some impact despite the survey period being prior before the increased social distancing measures as businesses “began to stand down or shed labour amid a reduction in turnover and expectations of tougher restrictions.”

GBP: Sterling recent rally came to a pause as risk sentiment soured seeing Cable move from highs of 1.2630 to lows of 1.2439. GBPUSD failed to breach it’s 200 dma at 1.2657 (a level to keep an eye on) while some highlight strong demand beneath 1.25. Number of new deaths continues to slow slightly in the UK although officials are waiting for further clarification before suggesting a peak has been reached. The Health Minister announced it is too early to make changes to lockdown measures, while high deaths will continue for a while. On Brexit, the UK is sticking to its roots and is not expected to request an extension by the end of June deadline, with negotiations set to take place on 20th April, 11th May and 1st of June via a video call.

EMFX: EMFX in general was weaker against the buck today amid soured risk appetite. ZAR, MXN & RUB underperformed amid a poor day for oil prices while some weakness in BRL was explained by the resignation of its Health Secretary amid indifferences with President Bolsonaro.

subject: CRUDE WRAP: WTI (K0) settled USD 0.24 lower at USD 19.87/bbl; Brent (M0) settled USD 1.91 lower at USD 27.69/bbl
analysis_details:
Crude futures continued their post-OPEC + decline on Wednesday as ballooning inventories, dismal IEA forecasts and US data, and little risk appetite all sunk their teeth. Prices continued lower in APAC and European trade, after the bearish private US inventories report on Tuesday, and particularly after the IEA posted its gloomy monthly report today (see below). At the same time, making the losses more acute was the paring of risk appetite in equities. The selling pressure found no reprieve in the US session either as the EIA weekly report showed crude stocks (bbls) building a record 19.2mln, gasoline +5mln, distillates +6mln; production fell by 100k BPD to 12.3mln BPD, although with storage reaching capacity, the cut will make little difference to the global supply glut. Elsewhere, Saudi Aramco has offered Asian and European refineries a payment deferral for crude cargoes by up to 90 days, sources reported; at least three refiners rejected the terms due to higher financing costs. However, Saudi later claimed such reports were false.

IEA MONTHLY OIL MARKET REPORT sees Global oil demand set to fall by a record 9.3mln BPD in 2020, potentially down by 29mln BPD in April. The report said SPR purchases could reach 200mln BPD in the next three months - still awaiting details on stock purchases. No feasible agreement could cut supply by enough to offset near-term demand losses - “however, the past week’s achievements are a solid start.” Predicts output falls by other countries, such as the US and Canada, could be around 3.5mln amid lower prices.

OPEC: Mexico will curtail production by 100k BPD in the months of May-June only, according to the Mexican Energy Minister; this is in-fitting with the OPEC+ pact announced over the weekend. OPEC initially wanted the country to cut output by 400k BPD, talks at the time hit a snag amid a rift between Saudi and Mexico. US stepped in as stated it will take some of the curtailment burden off Mexico (US committed to shoulder 250k BPD cuts on Mexico’s behalf). Meanwhile, in Russia, oil companies in the country are examining which wells they will curtail production at, looking mainly at mature fields where production was falling anyway, amid Moscow’s commitment for its largest-ever output cut, sources reported. Sources close to industry and government said that Moscow was preparing to cut its production by around 2mln BPD anyway amid the poor demand outlook.

Fed's Beige Book: Economic activity contracted sharply and abruptly across all regions in the US as a result of COVID-19; Most Districts reported declines in manufacturing, but cited significant variation across industries
content:
Economic Activity

  • The energy sector, suffering from low prices, reduced investment and output.
  • All Districts reported highly uncertain outlooks among business contacts, with most expecting conditions to worsen in the next several months.
  • Leisure and hospitality  were hardest hit, and retail, aside from essential goods
  • Producers of food and medical products reported strong demand but faced both production delays,
  • Districts reporting on loan demand said it was high, both from companies accessing credit lines and from households refinancing mortgages.

Employment and Wages

  • Employment declined in all Districts, steeply in many cases, as the COVID-19 pandemic affected firms in many sectors
  • Many Districts said severe job cuts were widespread, including the manufacturing and energy sectors
  • Several Districts noted they were cutting employment via temporary layoffs and furloughs that they hoped to reverse once business activity resumes.
  • The near-term outlook was for more job cuts in coming months.
  • No District reported upward wage pressures. 
  • Most cited general wage softening and salary cuts except for high-demand sectors such as grocery stores that were awarding temporary "hardship" or "appreciation" pay increases.

Prices

  • The general direction of price inflation was down for both selling prices and non-labor input prices, as Districts reported either slowing price growth, flat prices, or modest to moderate declines in prices on balance amid deterioration in demand
  • Four Districts also reported further declines in energy prices
  • supply chain disruptions and shifts in the composition of demand led to significant price increases for some essential services—such as freight—and some agricultural commodities and consumer goods. 
  • While expectations concerning agriculture prices were mixed, the outlook calls for further downward pressure on prices on average.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: BoC leaves Loonie (and markets) in the lurch
content:
CAD

Not the biggest G10 loser, but considerably weaker alongside crude prices amidst a broader downturn in risk sentiment. The Loonie was already losing momentum before Statistics Canada released its preliminary estimate of monthly GDP for March and handed back more gains vs its US peer when the flash figure printed at -9%. Usd/Cad rebounded through 1.4100 ahead of the BoC and only pulled pack partially below the big figure when rates were left on hold as widely anticipated and the Bank announced a delay to updated MPR forecasts due exceptionally high levels of uncertainty surrounding the economic outlook. However, the BoC did unveil fresh policy stimulus in the form of Provincial and Corporate bond QE, while enhancing its term repo facility to offer funding for up to 2 years and raising the amount of T-bills bought by up to 40% on a temporary basis. Usd/Cad currently around 1.4100 within a wide 1.3876-1.4123 range and not as volatile as option pricing predicted over the Central Bank event via a 102 pip break-even, or during the subsequent press conference.

DXY

The index and Greenback in general are off best levels, but still on course for a much improved performance and ending a run of consecutive negative sessions that started before Easter when the Fed delivered another aggressive anti-coronavirus lending scheme. The DXY remains comfortably above 99.500 and almost extended its recovery to 100.000, but seems to have been thwarted by psychological resistance and the later US macro releases having held up relatively well in the face of the bleak elements in the retail sales report and collapse in NY Fed manufacturing.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodean Dollars have been battling out down under for the dubious accolade of worst major performer and it’s still a close call between the high risk/beta currencies, as Aud/Usd strives to keep hold of the 0.6300 handle and Nzd/Usd hovers just below 0.6000. In short, the slide in oil and other commodities on top of overall risk aversion have undermined the Aussie and Kiwi, with the former now wary about looming jobs data.

JPY/CHF/EUR/GBP 

All unable to evade the fallout from renewed Buck buying that outweighed safe-haven demand for the Yen and Franc, albeit not in terms of crosses, while the Euro topped out ahead of 1.1000 and Sterling failed to sustain 1.2600+ levels well before succumbing to RHS Eur/Gbp orders for the 4 pm London fix that countered BoE headlines about potentially bigger purchases of Sterling supranational paper and reports that UK-EU trade talks were constructive on resumption.

SCANDI/EM 

No shock that the Nok, Rub, Mxn and Zar were rocked by the aforementioned reversal in oil and other commodities, but the Try only stopped the rot with the aid of Turkish bank intervention following a record monthly budget deficit.

ANALYSIS: Industrial production drops by the most since 1946, consistent with manufacturing contracting by 20% annualised, Capital Economics says
content:
• US industrial production dropped by a hefty 5.4% M/M in March - deeper than the 4.0% decline analysts had expected, and the largest monthly fall since 1946, once again highlighting that the manufacturing side of the economy is being hammered as much as the services side.  
  • Manufacturing production itself fell by 6.3% M/M, also the largest monthly drop since WW2, largely due to the fall in motor vehicle production, but every industry group saw output fall - even food and beverages, despite the panic buying seen in the month.  
  • "With many factories only being shut down in the last couple of weeks of last month, however, the March data will capture only part of the associated hit to activity," Capital Economics says, "indeed, the collapse in the Empire State manufacturing index to a record low of -78.2 in April, from -21.5, leaves it consistent with manufacturing output falling at a 20% annualised pace."

subject: BOC does not issue new economic forecasts due to the exceptionally high uncertainties around the outlook
US EQUITY OPEN: Indices in negative territory as sentiment takes a turn for the worse with Energy and Financials lagging
content:
MACRO: Risk-off has marked the start of Wednesday trade, US equities opened in the red by over 2%, following the downbeat tone in Europe, and Asia was mixed overnight. The Treasury curve is bull-flattening, in Europe there is a preference for the Bund over peripheral debt. Both Brent and WTI are in the red again amid continuing focus on the demand side of the equation, and today the IEA forecast global oil demand will fall to levels last seen in 1995. Gold is giving back some of Tuesday's gains, which saw it rise to 7-year highs.

SECTORS: A turnaround in sentiment today sees all sectors open in negative territory with defensives (XLP, XLV) the relative outperformers, and Health Care’s (XLV) losses limited by United Health (UNH) after its solid earnings report. However, Energy and Financials the underperformers with the former tracking the crude complex while the latter continues to see disappointment from earnings. Airlines are mostly green after striking a deal with the government for a bailout late Tuesday.

EARNINGS: Goldman Sachs (GS) missed on EPS but beat on revenue, while Provision for credit losses were at USD 937mln (exp. 550mln, prev. 224mln). Its FICC revenue was up 33% Y/Y to 2.97bln which saw its bond trading results the strongest in five years. Although overall, results were hit by debt and equity holdings in its asset management business, but its trading topped expectations. Bank of America (BAC) also missed on EPS, revenue also fell slightly short. Loan loss provisions increased to USD 4.8bln, above estimates. BAC saw a similar story to JPM where EPS took a hit on the increased credit provisions but NII and NIM were strong at 12.13bln and 2.91%, both above expectations. In a call however, its CFO noted NII could approach 11bln in Q2 and expects the largest COVID impact on NII in Q2, and its CEO highlighted it has had an impact on every part of its business. Citi (C) beat on both EPS and revenue, while credit provisions rose to 7.03bln from 2.22bln last quarter. Fixed Income Markets revenue rose 39% to USD 4.8bln, reflecting strength in rates, currencies and commodities. Equity Markets revenue that rose 39% to USD 1.2bln with strong performance in derivatives; includes higher client activity as a result of the higher volatility. Regional bank PNC Financial (PNC) beat on EPS and revenue, NII fell Q/Q, while credit loss provisions rose 693mln to 914mln. US Bancorp (USB) missed on EPS but beat on revenue while NII declined, Provision for credit losses stood at 993mln (+600mln); note some desks highlight the regional banks may have to increase its provisions in the upcoming quarters. Elsewhere, United Health (UNH) are firmer after a decent report with top and bottom-line beats while it maintained its FY EPS view, noting it does not request or plan to request any government aid.

STOCK STORIES: Airlines (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV, JBLU, ALK)  mostly firmer after the companies reached an agreement with the Treasury for payroll aid through the Payroll Support Program. Procter & Gamble (PG) increased its quarterly dividend by 6% to USD 0.79 and it also announced it is advancing its Q3 earnings release to April 17th from April 21st. Tesla (TSLA) China registrations rose 450% m/m to 12,079 units, according to LMC Automotive. Visa Inc. (V) & Mastercard (MA) were downgraded to Hold from Buy at Jefferies.

TECHNICALS: Credit Suisse' technicians note SPX resistance between 2,855-2,934 (coinciding with 61.8% of the Q1 collapse); NDX has cleared 8,572 resistance, opening the door to 9,000-9,102 (neckline of the Q1 top, and also around the 78.6% of the Q1 collapse) where it expects the index to attempt a top.

VIRUS CATALYSTS: As we have noted earlier in the week, analysts have been moving on from the case count and death toll; while a trend decline from peak rates is important, re-opening economies and seeing no signs of reinfections, as well as the development of vaccines and treatments is likely to drive the next leg higher. These conversations are occurring, and while there is the political distraction of US President Trump arguing with state governors, the conversation has begun not only in the US, but in other key markets around the world. Meanwhile on the treatment front, while many note that there are numerous treatments in development, these are only expected to be available to the wider markets in months (at minimum). Additionally, it is worth paying attention to commentary from large employers about when they intend to get their staff back into action. 

QUANT VIEW: The playbook of Nomura's quant desk - which we have covered quite a bit in recent notes - seems to be unfolding as planned, and they today reiterate their view for an ongoing natural rebound away from earlier pessimism, with the sustained downtrend in volatility inducing systematic buying by CTAs and risk-parity funds through to 22nd April in the NDX; Nomura says CTAs are relatively flat in SPX positioning, and expect that they will add to SPX longs in the next few days. However, looking at the sector performance, Nomura notes it has been the rally has been kept alive by large caps, and not a preference for higher-risk investment targets such as small caps, high-beta stocks, and value stocks. "We think investors would do well to keep in mind that when overdone pessimism corrects itself in the way we are currently seeing in US equities, there is no guarantee that the market will make the leap into outright optimism," the bank writes.

ANALYSIS: April Empire State Survey collapses, implying a 35.0 print for April's Manufacturing ISM, according to Pantheon Macroeconomics
content:
• Last month's record dropped was usurped by the April data, which saw a record fall of 56.7 points to -78.20, way below the Street's -35.0 expectation. To highlight the magnitude, analysts note that the low in 2008 was -34.3, making it clear that manufacturing is being hit as hard as the services sector.
  • The sub-indices all declined, with the exception of delivery times, which rose because supply chains have shut down, Pantheon said.
  • "The average level of the key Empire State components points to the national ISM manufacturing index falling to about 35; the December 2008 low was 34.5," Pantheon writes, "whether that level is undershot in April or May doesn’t matter; the point is that manufacturing is in meltdown."

subject: ANALYSIS: US retail sales core numbers potentially skewed higher, BMO says
analysis_details:
• Although monthly March retail sales data showed a decline deeper than analysts were expecting, some analysts took comfort in some of the internals; the control Group (which feeds into GDP) fell by 1.7%, not as bad as the -2.0% the Street was expecting.
  • BMO said that data collection was always going to be a concern, and notes the report stated "many businesses are operating in a limited capacity or have ceased operations completely. As a result, their ability to provide accurate, timely information to Census may be limited."
  • Additionally, the report said "data collection is now occurring primarily via email requests and online reporting"; BMO argues that this suggests that firms which are shut down are not reporting, therefore potentially skewing the core numbers higher.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 15th April 2020
content:
